awd_titl_txt: Ship Operations- R/V Marcus G. Langseth
awd_abstract_narration:
Lanseth provides the US academic community multi-channel seismic MCS capability, and over the last decade Langseth has worked throughout the world's oceans.  The unique capabilities of Langseth have enabled both 2D and 3D MCS experiments that required multiple hydrophone arrays and linear sound source airgun arrays.  Combined with the ability to carry large numbers of ocean-bottom seismometers for refraction seismology, this unique imaging capability has permitted NSF-sponsored scientists to study a wide range of marine Earth science problems.

R/V Langseth supports NSF work that has been peer-reviewed.  This first year annual report has gone to external panel.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE TRUSTEES OF COLUMBIA UNIVERSITY IN THE CITY OF NEW YORK

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Columbia University Lamont Doherty Earth Observatory

por.por_cntn:
R/V Marcus G. Langseth is an oceanographic research vessel that operates as part of the US Academic Research Fleet under an agreement with the National Science Foundation.  The ship is owned by Columbia University and operated by it's Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory.  It is one of five "global class" research vessels in the fleet that has the endurance and ability to travel the world's oceans.  Langseth also provides a unique seismic imaging capability to the fleet that allows scientists to image 10's of kilometers below the seafloor to better understand earth's tectonic systems and geohazards.

During 2024, Langseth supported six scientific missions that ranged widely through the Atlantic Ocean from up to  54°S in the Southern Ocean to as far north as 68°N (north of Iceland). The ship supported 296 days of science operations overail on a variety of projects. The scientific studies ranged from sampling seawater at strategic locations to study ocean currents/changes  to sediment cores to collecting moorings to two seismic imaging programs off Iceland's Reykjanes Ridge and the Chain Transform Fault in the  Equatorial Atlantic, respectively. The ship visited ports in the Cape Verde Islands, S. Africa, Namibia, New York and Reykjavik in support of the science projects that were led by scientists from around US with support from NOAA and NSF.  


Last Modified: 02/13/2025
Modified by: Sean M Higgins
